Strengths: great professors, great lectures, great books

I really liked how my professor would write the main points that we were to cover on the blackboard before class started - it helped to give a clear roadmap to what I should focus on and also helped when it came time for exam revision. The student-prepared starters were also excellent in beginning the discussion and even though handouts were optional, it was great to get a handout with a reconstruction of the argument. Even if an interpretation wasn't perfect, actually going through and clarifying parts of the text definitely helped my understanding.

I think the readings this term were incredible, and I was really able to get a broad sweep of ideas and how they developed with the times. Each time we read a new philosopher, I was forced to abandon all preconceived notions and really think about the variety of new perspectives that each successive author we read brought to the table (my concepts of morality changed endlessly). I think this really shows the excellent curation of the canon! As is always the case with DS though, it sometimes felt as though we had way too little time to really learn about a philosopher in depth, but I understand that it's a necessary trade-off.

Strengths: this course will guide you through some of the biggest philosophers since Descartes, works which are very difficult to do on your own. If you are interested in philosophy, it's a great start. Also-- Professor Russell is a fantastic teacher, and it is a shame that she will not be at Yale next year. She is super smart, kind, relatable, and funny. 
Weaknesses: That said, it is often a really frustrating course, especially because the texts are so lofty and full of jargon and complex systems that to endeavor to cover them in one or two classes often felt like a bit of a joke. Your ability to go in depth, to actually understand fully why someone believes what they believe, how their beliefs might operate in the real world, etc. is severely hindered by the speed and sheer volume of the course. There are two solutions to this; either assign less reading so we can actually cover and understand the full breadth of what we are reading (risking leaving things out, not getting a good picture of the philosopher...) or give us more time on some of the more complex philosophers like Hegel and Kant (which might mean reducing volume in other parts). I also think it is a big mistake to have one class, respectively, on each of the two female philosophers, Murdoch and DeBeauvoir. 

That said, I think this was a good introductory course to philosophy, which will challenge you and bring you to think of things in a different light.

I felt that the course was overall very strong. I would have appreciated more guidance in the larger concepts of some of the texts, particularly the more challenging ones like Kant and Hegel. I found that the difficulty of the texts made the class very challenging, and I would have appreciated more of a breakdown of the concepts. However, I felt that Professor Russell worked very hard to make these concepts accessible and understandable. I would have liked some of the lectures to be more engaging.

Overall, I thought this course was wonderful. However, I do wish that we got to read sample philosophy essays in class so that we know what standards of writing we are held to and know where to improve on our own essays.
